## Probability of Poker Hands ##

A hand in Texas Hold'em consists of 5 cards from a deck of 52 cards. A hand may fall into one of the following categories. We are going to compute the probability of each category.

First, the number of all possible hands is %s

### Pair: exactly one pair of equal rank cards ###

1.text: 1. The number of possibilities for the ranks of the pair is %s

2.text: 2. The number of possibilities for the suits of the pair is %s

3.text: 3. The three other cards have three ranks different from the pair, the number of possibilities for their ranks is %s

4.text: 4. And they can have any suit, thus the number of possibilities of their suites is %s

5.text: 5. Thus the number of hands with exactly one pair is %s

6.text: 6. The ratio of this number to the number of all hands %s

0-0.text: 1.1 Can the ranks of the pair be different? %s

0-1.text: 1.2 Does the rank of one card in the pair determine the rank of the other card in the pair? %s

0-2.text: 1.3 The number of possibilities for the rank of one card in the pair is %s

1-0.text: 2.1 Can the suits of the pair be the same? %s

1-1.text: 2.2 Would a hand with 10D, 10H be the same as a hand with 10H, 10D? %s

2-0.text: 3.1 Assume the rank of the pair is 10. How many possibilities are there for the rank of one of the other cards? %s

2-1.text: 3.2 Should you count a hand with ranks 10,10,J,K,A separately from a hand with ranks 10,10,K,J,A? %s

2-2.text: 3.3 Do the ranks of the remaining 3 cards need to be distinct? %s

2-3.text: 3.4 How many ways are there to rearrange (permute) the cards K,J,A? %s

2-4.text: 3.5 Since all permutations of K,J,A are counted as one choice of three ranks, your answer of [`12*11*10`] is overcounting by the number of ways to order 3 distinct elements. This is %s. After answering this, you should be able to answer the original question by dividing [`12*11*10`] by this amount.

3-0.text: 4.1 Could the three remaining cards have suits Diamond, Diamond, Diamond? %s

3-1.text: 4.2 How many ways are there to choose the suit of the first remaining card? %s

3-2.text: 4.3 How many ways are there to choose the suits of the two remaining cards? %s
